Award.AbstractNarration:
Computational topological methods are increasingly and successfully being used to analyze and understand complex data, provided both from experimental sources and numerical simulations. Many of these topological methods use homology theory and the related Betti numbers to concentrate on essential topological information. Usually the objects of interest are discretized before their homology can be computed. This process of discretization can introduce artifacts which cause the resulting topological information to be incorrect. Uncertainty can also occur in experimental settings due to noise.
In this project, the investigator and his colleagues develop two mechanisms for a quantitative assessment of the correctness of topological information.
The first approach is based on the realization that most applied problems involve randomness, and it studies the accuracy of homology computations for random fields by providing explicit probability estimates which give a-priori information on suitable problem discretizations. The second mechanism develops a method for rigorous computational a-posteriori correctness based on randomized subdivisions. In addition, the investigators address two specific applications which are interesting in their own right. First, they develop a new method for finding isolating blocks in dynamical systems, which has a wide range of possible applications and provides a novel tool for studying dynamical properties of evolution equations. The second application focuses on pattern classification in materials science and leads to a classification of possible phase separation phenomena in multi-component alloys.

Recent advances in computational sciences have led to an immense increase in the amount of generated data, and the development of novel techniques to quickly and reliably extract essential information from this data has become a central issue. The project research develops probabilistic approaches for topological data analysis, including quantitative reliability assessments.
The project has applications in the field of materials science, such as in the study of the properties of industrial level metal alloys and the design of new materials. Topological methods have already been shown to provide important insight into such materials studies, and the techniques developed in this project are applied in the context of materials characterization and design. This leads to a classification of phase separation phenomena in multi-component alloys and has the potential to lead to system-response-maps, which can then be used in the design of materials, such as for example the design of controlled drug-release coatings for arterial stents. The project also leads to a broader study of random fields using homology theory, which in the long term has applications in medical imaging. The project involves student research at both the undergraduate and graduate levels.

During the formation of metal alloys their internal fine structure experiencesdynamical changes which can profoundly impact their overall material properties.In particular in the context of composite materials, it is therefore essential tobe able to predict both the geometry and the time frame of such phase separationphenomena. To accomplish this, a variety of evolution equation models have beenproposed which allow for computer-simulated predictions. Yet, many of these modelsare phenomenological in nature, and one therefore has to be able to perform modelvalidations which relate the numerically predicted material microstructure to the ones created through often expensive experiments. This is complicated by thefact that the observed microstructures usually exhibit complicated geometries,such as the ones shown in Figures 1 through 3. Computational topological methodsare increasingly and successfully being used to analyze and understand such complexgeometries, provided both from experimental sources and numerical simulations. Manyof these topological methods use homology theory and the related Betti numbers toconcentrate on essential topological information. Usually, the objects of interestare discretized before their homology can be computed. This process of discretizationcan introduce artifacts which cause the resulting topological information to beincorrect. Uncertainty can also occur in experimental settings due to noise.
The research funded through this project has developed a number of mechanismsfor a quantitative assessment of the correctness of topological information,including quantitative reliability assessments. The PI, together with his collaboratorsand students, has developed an algorithm for rigorous computational a-posterioricorrectness verification of homology computations of microstructures. The algorithmuses a randomized subdivision technique to identify critical features in complexmicrostructures through an adaptive mechanism, which allows for the efficientcomputation and simultaneous verification of topological properties. The algorithmsignificantly decreases the computational effort of previous approaches, and providesverifiable metrics that can be used to related experimental to numerical data. In addition, the project has led to a novel approach for extracting inherent systemparameters from topological information based on the concept of persistence landscapes.The effectiveness of the analytical methods has been demonstrated in the context ofmulti-component metal alloys, as well as for models describing the formation ofdiblock copolymers.
Beyond the data analysis aspects described in the previous paragraph, the projecthas also been concerned with the validation of long-term predictions made bymathematical models for phase separation. This could be achieved by combining thevalidation algorithm developed in the first part of the project with Conley indextheory to identify global structures in dynamical systems, which in turn can beused to predict long-term limits of dynamical behavior. The method is based onrigorously validating isolating blocks, such as the one shown in Figure 4. Inaddition, the PI has developed rigorous computational methods to establishstationary states in infinite-dimensional evolution equations which describe phaseseparation in diblock copolymers. Such states serve both as long-term limits asorganizing centers for the dynamics. It was demonstrated that this equilibriumstructure can be used to explain complex phenomena such as the effects of thermalnoise on the creation of material droplets during a phase separation mechanismcalled nucleation.
